overview: From 2025-11-01 to 2025-12-01, ethereum-optimism/docs had 57 new PRs (56 merged), 4 new issues, and 69 active contributors.

topIssues.title: [DA Footprint Limit] Documentation
topIssues.author: geoknee
topIssues.body:
* Should emphasize the risks around setting the scalar 
  - too high (excludes too much traffic)
  - too low (ineffective at protecting against spam or DA backlogs, throttling becomes likely)
* When Gas Limit is changed, this scalar should also be changed 

---
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/317 WIP design doc
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/767 WIP specs
https://miro.com/app/board/uXjVJIlXd1Q=/ threat modelling

topIssues.title: ENV variables no longer available
topIssues.author: kamikazechaser
topIssues.body:
Previously, there were corresponding ENV variables description to the flags for both op-node and op-geth. Now it seems that only the flags are available e.g. at https://docs.optimism.io/node-operators/guides/consensus-config#consensus-layer-configuration-options-op-node.

Is it possible to restore this without anyone having to run the CLI?

topIssues.title: ## Description of the updates required
topIssues.author: cshein45
topIssues.body:
## Acceptance Criteria

- Updated section for MOVE token staking with clear parameters and benefits
- Visual diagram for DAO governance structure
- Inclusion of current community funding models (Ko-fi, grants, NFT utility)
- Bilingual content support (English + Burmese)

## Resources

- [Movement Wiki](https://wiki.movement.xyz/kokyat)
- [Whitepaper](https://www.movementnetwork.xyz/whitepaper/movement-whitepaper_en.pdf)
- [GitHub](https://github.com/movementlabsxyz)
- [Notion Spec](https://www.notion.so/1ab2c82b8cb580ccb5bdcf7625f72c86)
- SMEs: KoKyat, ThaeThae, HanGyi

## Action items

1. Review linked resources and meet with SMEs (KoKyat, etc.)
2. Write the first draft of updated content
3. Share draft with SMEs for feedback
4. Conduct peer review (e.g. HanGyi or ThaeThae)
5. Final SME approval
6. Publish on wiki.movement.xyz

## Github Issue Label Criteria

<details>
<summary>Priority</summary>

- `p-high`: This is important for public-facing DAO and token communication.

</details>

<details>
<summary>T-shirt size</summary>

- `s-M`: Moderate work requiring cross-team collaboration and translation.

</details>

<details>
<summary>Content evaluation</summary>

- `a-moderate`: The page requires several updates and partial rewrites.

</details>

## MDX Metadata Format

```mdx
---
title: "Movement DAO Governance & Token Utility"
tags: ["movement-network", "dao", "tokenomics", "funding"]
description: "Learn how the Movement Network organizes DAO governance, token staking, and community fundraising via onchain tools."
---

<details>
<summary>Component tags</summary>


l1-contracts
l2-contracts
standard-bridge
op-gov-token
op-program
op-node
dev-console

</details>


<details>
<summary>Engineering tags</summary>


eng-growth
eng-devx
eng-protocol

</details>
```



⸻

topIssues.title: [DOCS] Begin documenting `MinBaseFee` feature
topIssues.author: geoknee
topIssues.body:
<!-- please fill out the description and acceptance criteria to the best to your ability. While the other sections are optional, it makes resolving the issue much easier. -->

## Description 
<!-- Write a clear and concise description of the docs request. For example, is the request related to an existing page or are you suggesting a brand-new docs page? -->
We would like to start work documenting this feature currently in development: 



## Acceptance criteria
<!-- Clearly list out the definition of done. -->
*  Chain Operators need to be made aware that setting the minimum too high may have negative impacts on users (making transactions harder to get included). 
* Chain operators need to understand the manner by the parameter is set using a base 2 logarithm. 

## User stories
<!-- User stories that illustrate the benefits of this issue. For example, this documentation improvement will allow user X to be able to Y. -->


## Resources and support
<!-- Provide additional documentation, context, and subject matter experts to help us complete this issue. -->
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/295
SME: @geoknee, @joshklop , @sebastianst 

## Action items
<!-- Clear steps to take to complete this issue -->

topPRs.title: Add Actions SDK Reference Pages
topPRs.author: its-everdred
topPRs.body:
## Problem

At the moment, we only have a Quickstart guide for Actions SDK. We need additional detail.

## Solution

- [x] Add Configuring Actions Doc
- [x] Add Integrating Wallets Doc
- [x] Add Wallet API Doc
- [x] Add Lend API Doc
- [x] Add actions-sdk as a devDependency and script to generate doc components from inline docs
- [ ] Clean up script

topContributors.summary: sbvegan: Focused on critical documentation and registry updates, merging 12 PRs to support network communications and upgrades. They executed a major update to notice pages for communications in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1847` (+2155/-698 lines) and managed key details for the Jovian hard fork, including updating release information in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1852`. In addition to these direct contributions, sbvegan was an active collaborator, providing 25 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on maintaining and improving project documentation.

devin-ai-integration: Focused on improving the quality and clarity of documentation and contract specifications for the Ethereum Optimism project. They made several impactful enhancements to the specifications, most notably by linking defined terms to their definitions in a large refactor (`specs#856`, +274/-225 lines), adding a new `SuperFaultDisputeGame` variant (`specs#852`), and cleaning up existing contract specs (`specs#853`, `specs#854`). This was complemented by a broad effort across 12 separate pull requests to fix typos and grammatical errors throughout the `ethereum-optimism/docs` repository, demonstrating a clear focus on improving overall documentation and specification quality.

ajsutton: Focused on supporting the team through collaboration this month. They contributed to project progress by providing 3 pull request reviews, which included 2 approvals. Additionally, they participated in discussions by commenting on one issue.
joshklop: No activity this month.

smartcontracts: Focused on improving CI processes and contributing to future design this month, merging a pull request to enhance upgrade tests in CI (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18133). They also authored a significant design document for OPCM v2 (ethereum-optimism/design-docs#353) and were highly engaged in supporting the team's work, providing 30 code reviews. Their contributions show a focus on development infrastructure, design, and team collaboration.

maurelian: This month, maurelian focused on development tooling and new features, merging a PR to optimize the build process in `op-deployers` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18130). They also proposed a new `DeployFeesDepositor` script (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18223) and provided significant team support by conducting 16 code reviews. Based on their code changes, their work was primarily centered on feature development and testing.

bitwiseguy: This month, bitwiseguy focused on maintaining the deployment tooling, with their primary contribution being the support for the `op-contracts/v5.0.0-rc.2` upgrade in the `op-deployer` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18154). They also fixed related test timeouts in the CLI runner via PR ethereum-optimism/optimism#18179. In addition to their own changes, they actively supported the team by providing 8 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on bug fixes and testing within the deployment process.

pcw109550: Focused on node synchronization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, proposing a significant Proof of Concept for a "Light CL" in `op-node` (optimism#18196). In support of this effort, they identified and created three issues related to node syncing and potential bugs (#18124, #18125, #18126). While their primary development work was on this open PR, they also actively supported the team by conducting 14 code reviews. Their code changes, which modified 34 files, were primarily focused on bug fixes and tests.
geoknee: Contributed by reviewing and approving one pull request.

sebastianst: Focused on significant refactoring and modularization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository to improve its core architecture. They led this effort by moving fork names into a new package (#18121) and relocating package predeploys (#18145), both substantial architectural changes. Alongside this refactoring, sebastianst also fixed a configuration loading bug in the batch decoder (#18209) and actively supported the team by providing 17 code reviews.

JosepBove: Focused on operational maintenance in the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository, merging two PRs to update an RPC configuration and apply a bugfix for betanets (#1281, #1280). They were also an active collaborator, providing 7 reviews and 5 comments on other pull requests. Their contributions were primarily focused on bug fixes and other work, with a third of their file modifications involving documentation.

mds1: Focused on CI and deployment pipeline maintenance this month, merging 6 small PRs to address bugs and configuration issues. In addition to their own fixes, mds1 was an active collaborator, providing 19 code reviews for teammates.
